image.altText: A drone shot of a suburban housing estate.

items.synopsis: National house prices lifted sharply in May, according to data from CoreLogic. Sydney continues to lead the recovery, with rises across the capital cities, as the number of properties advertised for sale fell further.

title.children: Property price rebound gathering pace despite interest rate rises

image.altText: A worker lifts the top off a large grey and black battery.

items.synopsis: As Australia passes the milestone of 100,000 electric vehicles on our roads, an environmental downside is looming: huge numbers of batteries that could end up in landfill.

title.children: Electric vehicles are touted as key to a green future. But their batteries pose a triple-threat

image.altText: Composite Canberra Liberals MLA Jeremy Hanson and Health Minister Rachel Stephen Smith

items.synopsis: Controversial legislation enabling the ACT government to take over Calvary Public Hospital is passed in the Legislative Assembly.

title.children: ACT government given green light for Calvary hospital takeover after Legislative Assembly debate

image.altText: Left to right: June Oscar, Ian Hamm, Fred Hooper, Miriam-Rose Ungunmerr Baumann

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Elders share stories and language, culture and wisdom, that have been passed down from generation to generation.

title.children: How Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Elders have shaped culture and country for tens of thousands of years

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: Perhaps it was no accident that Philip Lowe used his Senate Estimates appearance to give the political class some advice about the need to rethink how Australia fights inflation, even if he knew his words would likely fall on deaf ears, writes David Speers.

title.children: At his last stand, Lowe gave some tough advice to the 'political class'. Then the inflation figures dropped

image.altText: Cameron Murray and Nathan Cleary look sad

items.synopsis: Desperate defence, a contentious sin-binning and a prop taking to the air all contributed to one of the most dramatic and unlikely State of Origin wins in Queensland history. Here's the five main talking points.

title.children: Miracle try savers, controversial bunker calls and a flying prop: Five things we learned from Origin I

image.altText: Two men celebrate after winning a State of Origin match

items.synopsis: After Queensland found all the answers in State of Origin I, New South Wales leaves Adelaide with nothing but more questions.

title.children: Why Queensland's triumph in Adelaide is yet another spin on the classic Maroons story

image.altText: a man looking

items.synopsis: The Victoria Cross recipient sued the Sydney Morning Herald, The Age, The Canberra Times and three journalists in the Federal Court over a series of articles published in 2018. Today Justice Anthony Besanko will deliver his judgement.

title.children: Judgment in Ben Roberts-Smith's extraordinary defamation battle set to be delivered

image.altText: Generic close-up shot of blue and white police tape.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Two men dead after being run over, and swan babies rescued after mother is killed. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has outlined its intention to regulate artificial intelligence, saying there are gaps in existing law and new forms of AI technology will need "safeguards" to protect society. Industry and Science Minister Ed Husic tells ABC News Breakfast that the government is open to banning "high risk" AI technologies, but is consulting with the sector. "Where there is a clear high risk, that is one of the options that is on the table," he says. "We want to go through the consultation process. We don't want to put the cart before the horse, as it were, here. We want people to have their say. "But, clearly, where there are things that the public are saying in very loud terms that they want us to be able to respond and manage, then we want to have those options on the table, absolutely."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Science minister says banning 'high risk' artificial intelligence is an option

props.alt: A middle-aged man in a suit does a TV interview in front of a backdrop showing parliament house in Canberra

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
The federal government has outlined its intention to regulate artificial intelligence, saying there are gaps in existing law and new forms of AI technology will need "safeguards" to protect society.
Industry and Science Minister Ed Husic tells ABC News Breakfast that
the government is open to banning "high risk" AI technologies
, but is consulting with the sector.
"Where there is a clear high risk, that is one of the options that is on the table," he says.
"We want to go through the consultation process. We don't want to put the cart before the horse, as it were, here. We want people to have their say.
"But, clearly, where there are things that the public are saying in very loud terms that they want us to be able to respond and manage, then we want to have those options on the table, absolutely."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two men have died after being run over by a ute on the South Coast of New South Wales, and police are investigating whether they were lying on the road. Police say they were called to North Nowra at around 7pm on Wednesday night and found two men, aged 36 and 41, with critical injuries. Bystanders are said to have provided first aid until paramedics arrived, but both men died at the scene. "Officers attached to the South Coast Police District are investigating reports that the men may have been lying on the road when they were run over by a utility being driven by a 27-year-old man, " NSW Police says in a statement. The driver was taken to hospital to undergo mandatory testing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two men run over and killed on NSW South Coast

props.alt: A close up of police crime scene tape

children.content: (ABC News)
Two men have died after being run over by a ute
on the South Coast of New South Wales, and police are investigating whether they were lying on the road.
Police say they were called to North Nowra at around 7pm on Wednesday night and found two men, aged 36 and 41, with critical injuries.
Bystanders are said to have provided first aid until paramedics arrived, but both men died at the scene.

"Officers attached to the South Coast Police District are investigating reports that the men may have been lying on the road when they were run over by a utility being driven by a 27-year-old man, " NSW Police says in a statement.
The driver was taken to hospital to undergo mandatory testing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's Thanasi Kokkinakis has beaten Swiss tennis player Stan Wawrinka to reach the third round of the French Open. Kokkinakis fought back from a set down to win 3-6, 7-5, 6-3, 6-7, 6-3 in a match lasting four hours and 38 minutes. Fellow Australian Jason Kubler lost to Italy's Fabio Fognini in straight sets, while in the women's draw Storm Hunter had a three-set loss to Ukraine's Elina Svitolina.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia's Thanasi Kokkinakis stages comeback to defeat Stan Wawrinka

props.alt: A male tennis player sits courtside after a game with his hands on his head and smiles

children.content: (Reuters: Clodagh Kilcoyne)
Australia's Thanasi Kokkinakis has beaten Swiss tennis player
Stan Wawrinka to reach the third round of the French Open.
Kokkinakis
fought back from a set down to win 3-6, 7-5, 6-3, 6-7, 6-3
in a match lasting four hours and 38 minutes.
Fellow Australian Jason Kubler lost to Italy's Fabio Fognini in straight sets, while in the women's draw Storm Hunter had a three-set loss to Ukraine's Elina Svitolina.

items.synopsis: Australian kids in out-of-home-care usually go through multiple placements and rarely get therapeutic support to deal with trauma. A new model of care that pays mental health experts to become full-time foster parents aims to change that.

image.altText: a man wearing dark glasses leaving court

image.altText: A smoker lights up a cigarette

items.synopsis: Health warnings on individual cigarettes and new graphic images on cigarette packets are among changes the federal government plans to introduce.

title.children: Tobacco industry to face tougher restrictions by 2025 under planned laws

image.altText: Antarctica hits new low sea ice extent

items.synopsis: Antarctica's sea ice is now reforming as the continent moves deeper into the austral winter, but it's currently the smallest it has ever been for this time of year on record. This blip in the Antarctic pulse is the latest in a string of record lows that is being watched carefully by scientists.

title.children: A stutter in Earth's icy heartbeat has 'gravely concerned' scientists searching for answers
